Description: Hope4 is a charity in Rugby, working with hungry, homeless and badly-housed people. Within the work of Hope4 are the Rugby Foodbank, The Hope Centre and the Rugby Winter Shelter. For more information see our website: www.hope4.org.uk The Hope Centre, due to Covid-19 restricitions, is currently open 5 days a week by appointment and provides the following help: Homeless and badly housed people are helped in various ways by our skilled staff including with: Important Covid 19 update Hope4 is always very pleased to receive donations towards helping people who are homeless or temporarily housed in Rugby. As of July 2020 The Hope Centre is open (by appointment) and is able to continue its vital work with its clients, thorough its Key Worker staff and partner agencies in the town following strict Covid 19 health and safety guidelines.  Thank you for your support!

We don’t think anyone in our community should have to face going hungry. That’s why we provide three days’ nutritionally balanced emergency food and support to local people who are referred to us in crisis. We are part of a nationwide network of foodbanks, supported by The Trussell Trust, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK.  Salisbury Foodbank has provided emergency food to more than 5,000 people in the last year.  We need your support to continue to do this.  For more information visit our website at www.salisbury.foodbank.org.uk, find us on Facebook, Instagram or Twitter. Thank you for your generous support.

Osmani Trust whose vision is to help ordinary people do extraordinary things. We are a youth and community organisation based in Tower Hamlets amongst the heart of London’s urban deprivation and disadvantage. We help communitiesre engage with mainstream society in order to improve their quality of life. The Osmani Trust was created following the merger in 2009 of Elite Youth (1973) and Brick Lane Youth Development Association (1989).  Barriers to housing are in the top 2% most deprived. This is closely followed by low income at 9% and living environment 12% most deprived. Tower Hamlets sees some of the highest paid jobs alongside the highest levels of child povertydue to social exclusion and material deprivation. We know that children living in poverty experience more disadvantage and suffer poorer health and die younger. Crime deprivation falls within the top 40%of most deprived areas nationally; 66% of female inmates and 59% of male inmates have dependants under the age of 18 in Tower Hamlets. The number of displaced children with a parent in prison increases the vulnerability and risk of young people being attracted to joining a gang and a life of crime as this is what they feel will provide them with a sense of belonging and togetherness.  Employment barriers lie at 28% most deprived and educational deprivation lies at 33%, many of our young people report that they do not have the space at home to study due to overcrowding and thus reach lower levels of educational attainment. The impact of this can lead to them either becoming victims or perpetrators of crime, which results in them having lower paid jobs. Health barriers lie at a striking 26% most deprived, with a high number of families caring for disabled members they are more likely to remain in poverty, due to the high costs of caring. Especially as larger families are at a significantly higher risk of poverty. We have the 8th highest rate of Sexually Transmitted Infections in the country.  With so many challenges there is no surprise that our workers report that young people are struggling to strive and succeed in finding, gaining and sustaining employment. They struggle to make healthy and informed choices about their future. Our projects aim to help them break the cycle of crime and injustice they face due to the deprivation they live in and help them to lead extraordinary lives. Please kindly consider supporting our appeal and help us sustain a healthy future for the vulnerable young people and families in Tower Hamlets.

Hope4 is a charity in Rugby, working with hungry, homeless and badly-housed people. Within the work of Hope4 are the Rugby Foodbank, The Hope Centre and the Rugby Winter Shelter. For more information see our website: www.hope4.org.uk The Hope Centre, due to Covid-19 restricitions, is currently open 5 days a week by appointment and provides the following help: Homeless and badly housed people are helped in various ways by our skilled staff including with: Important Covid 19 update Hope4 is always very pleased to receive donations towards helping people who are homeless or temporarily housed in Rugby. As of July 2020 The Hope Centre is open (by appointment) and is able to continue its vital work with its clients, thorough its Key Worker staff and partner agencies in the town following strict Covid 19 health and safety guidelines.  Thank you for your support!

The Basingstoke Foodbank provides emergency food and support to local people in the Basingstoke and Tadley areas who are in crisis and in danger of going hungry. Foodbanks are an emergency food service.  We receive and store food donated by individuals, church groups and local businesses and we give out food parcels, in exchange for vouchers issued by our 3rd party partner agencies, who have issued them to their clients as they have judged that they are in crisis. As a result of the need for social distance that Covid19 demands, we are no longer able to see Clients face to face with their vouchers; instead, we  are receiving vouchers electronically from our partner agencies and then volunteer drivers deliver food parcels to Clients' homes.  We follow up our delivery to the Client by phone to see if there is anything more can be done to help them whilst they are in such a low ebb.  We offer to pray with / for the Clients if they are happy for us to do so. At the time of this update, September 2020, we are presently helping every month this year more than twice the number of people we were helping in the corresponding month in 2019.

We are one of the Trussell Trusts network of foodbanks with distribution centres in Epsom, Ewell, Leatherhead, Tadworth and Banstead.  We first opened our doors in October 2012 and since that date have fed and supported many local people. We are able to provide long life food, toiletries and a listening ear to those who need it most. Over the last 5 years we have fed over 18,500 people with 250 tonnes of donated food.   The food is donated by local people - through churches, schools, supermarket collections and local businesses - for local people.

Every day people in the UK go hungry for reasons ranging from redundancy to receiving an unexpected bill on a low income. West Lothian Food bank is a Trussell Trust food bank which provides a minimum of three days emergency food and support to people experiencing crisis. Rising food and fuel prices, static incomes, underemployment and changes to benefits are some of the reasons why increasing numbers are being referred to food banks for emergency food. The Trussell Trust partners with churches and communities to open new food banks nationwide. Our goal is for every person in West Lothian to have a distribution centre within easy reach. Your money pays for essential staff, a warehouse/office and the resourcing of 10 distribution centres across West Lothian. Visit our website regularly for updates on how your money is reaching people in need.

We are an independent foodbank charity (with one foodbank in Bow and a second in Bethnal Green) that has served the local community since 2014.  We are open to those in need of food support without referral.    Currently, during the continued COVID crisis, we are offering pre-bagged items + fresh fruit and veg once a week, with some extra food for families with children. Pre the COVID-19 crisis in March 2020 we supported around 100 clients each week. Since then we have seen a staggering increase in those seeking help- and are now supporting over 1,000 clients each week, with extra support for over 2,400 children.  We desperately need your financial support. With foodbills approaching £10,000 each week, more than ever we need your help to be able to continue to meet the needs of those in emergency food poverty in Tower Hamlets.  We are very grateful for whatever help you can give us, but please think about signing up for a regular donation as this gives us some clarity for the future.  £15 will allow us to support a family with enough basic food to keep them going for 3 days- and an extra £10 will pay for welfare and benefits advice for that family.  With thanks from the whole team at Bow Foodbank.
